questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presents with hypoglycemia. The intern starts a dextrose infusion and very soon finds that the patient develops global confusion and ophthalmoplegia. The diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Wernicke's encephalopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In chronic alcoholics, administering dextrose without thiamine can trigger Wernicke's encephalopathy , presenting with global confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia due to acute thiamine deficiency.
  • ➤ Wernicke's encephalopathy

questions.text: 5-Fluoro-Uracil causes thymine-less cell death after getting converted to a product. Which enzyme is inhibited here?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Thymidylate synthase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 5-Fluoro-Uracil inhibits thymidylate synthase , leading to a lack of thymine and causing "thymine-less" cell death. Additionally, methotrexate inhibits dihydrofolate reductase , further impairing thymine synthesis by preventing the regeneration of tetrahydrofolate.
  • ➤ 5-Fluoro-Uracil inhibits thymidylate synthase
  • ➤ methotrexate inhibits dihydrofolate reductase

questions.text: Diarrhea caused by cholera toxin involves which receptor:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) GM1 ganglioside receptor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cholera toxin causes diarrhea by binding to the GM1 ganglioside receptor , which facilitates toxin entry into cells, leading to increased cAMP and severe diarrhea. The complex structure of GM1 ganglioside makes it the ideal receptor for cholera toxin.
  • ➤ GM1 ganglioside receptor

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy with cystic fibrosis has developed malabsorption syndrome secondary to pancreatic insufficiency. He has dry skin, a scaly rash, hair loss, and poor wound healing. A deficiency of which of the following substances can explain his skin manifestations?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Linoleic acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A deficiency in linoleic acid , an essential omega-6 fatty acid, can lead to dry skin, scaly rash, hair loss, and poor wound healing, especially in cases of fat malabsorption, as seen in patients with cystic fibrosis and pancreatic insufficiency.
  • ➤ linoleic acid

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with muscle ache, hypotonia, and poor exercise tolerance. Further investigation reveals myoglobinuria and elevated creatine kinase enzyme levels in the blood. A deficiency of which transporter is responsible for the pathophysiology of the disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Carnitine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Carnitine deficiency prevents fatty acids from entering the mitochondria, leading to energy deficiency in muscles, which manifests as poor exercise tolerance, muscle pain, myoglobinuria, and elevated creatine kinase levels.
  • ➤ Carnitine deficiency

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is being evaluated for anosmia, deafness, and unstable gait. Further investigation reveals retinitis pigmentosa on fundoscopy and cardiac rhythm abnormalities on ECG. A rare congenital disease affecting lipid metabolism is being suspected. Deficiency of which of the following enzymes is expected to be found in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Phytanoyl CoA α-hydroxylase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Refsum disease is caused by a deficiency of phytanoyl CoA α-hydroxylase , leading to the accumulation of phytanic acid and resulting in symptoms such as retinitis pigmentosa, anosmia, deafness, and cardiac arrhythmias.
  • ➤ Refsum disease
  • ➤ phytanoyl CoA α-hydroxylase

questions.text: In a reaction, the substrate is available in a concentration that is 1000 times the Km value of the enzyme. After 9 minutes of reaction, 1% of the substrate is converted to product (12 microgram/ml). If the concentration of the enzyme is changed to 1/3 and the concentration of the substrate is doubled, what is the time taken to convert the substrate into the same amount of product, i.e., 12 microgram/ml?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 27 minutes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In zero-order kinetics , the reaction rate is independent of substrate concentration but directly proportional to enzyme concentration. Reducing the enzyme concentration increases the reaction time proportionally.
  • ➤ zero-order kinetics

questions.text: The graph shown below is the titration curve of a biochemical compound. Which of the following statements is true?

options.label: A
options.text: The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B

options.label: B
options.text: The points A and B represent the range of maximum ionization of the amine and carboxyl group

options.label: C
options.text: The compound has three ionisable side chains

options.label: D
options.text: The compound has one ionisable group

questions.correct_answer: A. The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The titration curve shows two ionizable groups , and the maximum buffering capacity occurs at points A and B , where the pH remains relatively constant despite the addition of NaOH.
  • ➤ two ionizable groups
  • ➤ maximum buffering capacity
  • ➤ A
  • ➤ B

questions.text: The common precursor amino acid for urea, creatine, and nitric oxide is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arginine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Arginine is the precursor for urea, creatine, and nitric oxide, playing crucial roles in the urea cycle, creatine synthesis, and nitric oxide production.
  • ➤ Arginine

questions.text: In urea cycle disorders, which of the following can be used to reduce the levels of ammonia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Phenylbutyrate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phenylbutyrate is used to treat urea cycle disorders by reducing ammonia levels through its conversion to phenylacetate, which binds to glutamine, forming a compound that is excreted in urine.
  • ➤ Phenylbutyrate

questions.text: Which of the following are products of triacylglycerol breakdown and subsequent β-oxidation that may undergo gluconeogenesis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Propionyl-CoA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Propionyl-CoA , produced from the β-oxidation of odd-chain fatty acids, is the only product from triacylglycerol breakdown that can undergo gluconeogenesis. Acetyl-CoA and ketone bodies cannot be converted to glucose.
  • ➤ Propionyl-CoA

questions.text: The problem of regenerating NAD+ from NADH for cytoplasmic processes by using mitochondria is solved in the most energy-efficient manner by which of the following?

options.label: A
options.text: Reversing the direction of enzyme reactions like pyruvate dehydrogenase

options.label: B
options.text: Locating certain cytochromes in the cytoplasm

options.label: C
options.text: Shuttling of coupled reaction substrates like malate to aspartate

questions.correct_answer: C. Shuttling of coupled reaction substrates like malate to aspartate
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Shuttling of coupled reaction substrates like malate to aspartate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The malate-aspartate shuttle is the most energy-efficient system for regenerating NAD+ from NADH produced in the cytoplasm, allowing NADH to be used in the mitochondria for ATP production.
  • ➤ malate-aspartate shuttle
  • ➤ NAD+
  • ➤ NADH

questions.text: A certain class of disease is produced because of the tissue’s lack of certain metabolic pathways. Which one of the following tissues can metabolize glucose, fatty acids, and ketone bodies for ATP production?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Muscle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Muscle is the tissue that can metabolize glucose , fatty acids , and ketone bodies for ATP production, making it versatile in energy utilization under different physiological conditions.
  • ➤ Muscle
  • ➤ glucose
  • ➤ fatty acids
  • ➤ ketone bodies

questions.text: A previously normal 2-month-old Caucasian girl is evaluated because of jittery spells (trembling, irritability) several hours after meals. A low blood glucose value is noted, and physical examination demonstrates a liver edge two finger-breadths below the right costal margin. Percussion confirms slight liver enlargement. Hospital testing reveals that the infant can increase her blood glucose after breastfeeding but cannot maintain normal levels 3 to 4 hours after feeding. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Galactosemia with inability to convert lactose to glucose

options.label: C
options.text: Fructosemia with inability to liberate sucrose from glucose

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Glycogen storage disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The glycogen storage disease presents with hepatomegaly and fasting hypoglycemia due to the liver’s inability to properly metabolize glycogen, resulting in difficulty maintaining blood glucose levels several hours after feeding.
  • ➤ glycogen storage disease
  • ➤ hepatomegaly
  • ➤ fasting hypoglycemia

questions.text: Which reaction in the diagram below would be inhibited in the presence of large amounts of avidin, an egg white protein that binds and sequesters biotin?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of avidin , which binds and sequesters biotin, inhibits the biotin-dependent enzyme pyruvate carboxylase , blocking the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, as represented by reaction C in the diagram.
  • ➤ avidin
  • ➤ biotin-dependent enzyme pyruvate carboxylase
  • ➤ reaction C

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding liver enzyme dephosphorylation to phosphorylation?

options.label: C
options.text: More commonly seen in fed state than in fasting state

options.label: D
options.text: Always activated by cAMP dependent tyrosine kinase

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Catecholamines stimulate it

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phosphorylation of liver enzymes is stimulated by catecholamines and is typically seen in the fasting state , when hormones like glucagon and epinephrine activate the cAMP-PKA pathway , leading to enzyme regulation for metabolic control.
  • ➤ catecholamines
  • ➤ fasting state
  • ➤ glucagon
  • ➤ epinephrine
  • ➤ cAMP-PKA pathway

questions.text: 2,4-Dinitrophenol (DNP), an uncoupler of oxidative phosphorylation, was used as a weight-loss agent in the 1930s. Reports of fatal overdoses led to its discontinuation in 1939. Which of the following would most likely be true concerning individuals taking 2,4-DNP?

options.label: A
options.text: ATP levels in the mitochondria are greater than normal

options.label: B
options.text: Body temperature is elevated as a result of hypermetabolism

options.label: C
options.text: The proton gradient across the inner mitochondrial membrane is greater than normal

options.label: D
options.text: The rate of electron transport is abnormally low

questions.correct_answer: B. Body temperature is elevated as a result of hypermetabolism
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Body temperature is elevated as a result of hypermetabolism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DNP acts as an uncoupler by disrupting the proton gradient , leading to inefficient ATP production and increased heat production (hypermetabolism), which results in elevated body temperature .
  • ➤ uncoupler
  • ➤ proton gradient
  • ➤ inefficient ATP production
  • ➤ heat production
  • ➤ elevated body temperature

questions.text: In this transamination reaction (shown in the diagram), which of the following are the products X and Y:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Aspartate, α-ketoglutarate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a transamination reaction, oxaloacetate is converted to aspartate , and glutamate is converted to α-ketoglutarate . This reaction is catalyzed by transaminases , and the cofactor for this process is vitamin B6 (pyridoxal phosphate) .
  • ➤ oxaloacetate
  • ➤ aspartate
  • ➤ glutamate
  • ➤ α-ketoglutarate
  • ➤ transaminases
  • ➤ vitamin B6 (pyridoxal phosphate)

questions.text: Restriction fragment length polymorphism analysis can only be used to follow the inheritance of a genetic disease if:

options.label: A
options.text: mRNA probe is used in combination with antibodies

options.label: B
options.text: The mutation is at or closely linked to restriction site

options.label: C
options.text: Mutation are outside of restriction sites so that cleaving still occurs

options.label: D
options.text: Restriction fragment remains the same size but their charge changes

questions.correct_answer: B. The mutation is at or closely linked to restriction site
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The mutation is at or closely linked to restriction site

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For RFLP to be effective, the mutation must either occur at or be closely linked to a restriction enzyme site , which alters the pattern of DNA fragments produced by the enzyme. This technique is useful for identifying point mutations and following the inheritance of genetic diseases such as sickle cell anemia .
  • ➤ RFLP
  • ➤ restriction enzyme site
  • ➤ point mutations
  • ➤ sickle cell anemia

questions.text: SYBR green dye is used in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Real time PCR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ SYBR green dye is a fluorescent dye used in real-time PCR to monitor and quantify the amount of double-stranded DNA produced during the amplification process. This enables real-time monitoring, making the process also known as quantitative PCR .
  • ➤ SYBR green dye
  • ➤ real-time PCR
  • ➤ quantitative PCR

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins can act without phosphorylation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lipoamide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lipoamide is the only one among these vitamins that can act without phosphorylation, making it an exception compared to pyridoxine, niacin, and thiamine.
  • ➤ Lipoamide

questions.text: A lethal mutation occurs in a bacterium, rendering it incapable of replicating its chromosome. Because of this mutation, DNA synthesis produces many short fragments of DNA that have RNA sequences at their 5’ ends. The mutation is most likely in a gene encoding which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) DNA polymerase I

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prokaryotic and Eukaryotic DNA Polymerase
  • ➤ Prokaryotic DNA Polymerase
  • ➤ Eukaryotic DNA Polymerase

questions.text: Which of the following is synthesized by DNA primase during replication?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) RNA primer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DNA primase synthesizes the RNA primer , which is essential for initiating DNA synthesis during replication.
  • ➤ DNA primase
  • ➤ RNA primer

questions.text: 7-methyl-guanosine triphosphate capping of the primary transcript is necessary for:

options.label: A
options.text: Processing of the primary transcript to mRNA

options.label: C
options.text: Protection of the mRNA against nucleolytic attack by 5'- exonucleases

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The 7-methyl-guanosine cap added to the 5' end of the mRNA is crucial for its processing, stability, and translation. It protects the mRNA from exonuclease attack and is essential for protein synthesis.
  • ➤ 7-methyl-guanosine cap

questions.text: Wobble hypothesis explains which of the following concepts of the genetic code?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Degeneracy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Wobble hypothesis explains the degeneracy of the genetic code by allowing flexibility in the third position of a codon, enabling multiple codons to code for the same amino acid.
  • ➤ Wobble hypothesis
  • ➤ degeneracy
